intro: Anchusa undulata var. commutata, commonly known as the wrinkled blueweed, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and thrives in full sun. Its leaves are undulating and often have a rough texture, while the flowers are clustered in dense, terminal spikes. This variety is noted for its ornamental value in gardens and its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
